subject: Design : OEM-BIOS Firmware update design document.

comments.message: The commit message title could be more specific. Also please find my comments inline.
spell check forrwards -> forwards. Ipmbbridged forwards the response to ocp-bicd daemon.
This may needs to updated: The existing redfish commands for firmware update will be supported for BMC, BIOS, CPLD updates.

Today, the interface uses IPMB, but we are transitioning to MCTP over I3C on YV3.5 so this needs to encompass both transport mechanisms.

In addition, there are BICs which talk to BICs on add-in cards so BICs not only talk to hosts, but to other BICs which talk to ASICs on these add-in cards.
We do use the BIC on many systems than just Yv2, but Yv2 is the only one where we've contributed code to openbmc/openbmc for now.  We plan to start on Yv3.5 very soon.

I'm not positive what this sentence means.

I think you are referring to RDE?  Probably should be explicit (and add a hyperlink to an RDE definition at DMTF)?

There is also a chance we'll use MCTP or PLDM instead of RDE.  It is undecided.
OEM commands should be initiated from a new daemon within a new repository in openbmc.

As an example, OEM BIOS and CPLD upgrades are performed using OEM commands.  To handle this, we will need a service to handle the BIC related features.

The above two lines should be placed before "These OEM commands..." to have the context flow right.

This design document focuses on OEM commands for OCP multi-host platforms.  The expectation is the service will implement OEM commands for platform specific operations such as firmware updates for CPLD, voltage regulators, BIOS and BICs.
The first platform we plan to support is Yosemite V2.
This section reads like a design proposal and not background, since you're talking about `ocp_bicd`.
Where is the ipmid involved in BMC->Host?  I don't see it in the picture and I don't recall it in the design.
This is confusing as previously, it mentioned the BMC communicates to the host through the BIC.  Are these daemons an implementation of the BIC support or something else?  It isn't clear.

Ipmid and ipmbridged are the daemons involved in Host to BMC communication. All the IPMI commands from Host to BMC and BMC to hosts are routed via these daemons only. This is not the BIC implementation.

I just added ipmid daemon, It will be used for BMC to host communication. It has handler functions of all IPMI commands. There is no scope for ipmid here. So not added in the picture. I have removed from ipmid from this doc.
Please make consistent the capitalization of acronyms.  OEM, IPMB, etc.  I see you using different cases throughout the document.

These IPMB and OCP-specific OEM commands are sent and received via the BIC.

Since you have defined BIC as Bridge IC previously, you can use BIC throughout the rest of the document instead of going back and forth.
This sentence is confusing and unclear.  What is the same and which commands are you expecting to use this interface?

The ipmbbridged is the daemon, all the IPMB commands are routed from host to BMC
through this daemon only. This ipmbbridged daemon also routes the IPMI commands to 
ocp_bicd. Updated the same in the doc.
"will implement complete features like firmware upgrade"

Firmware update OEM commands are initiated from the ocp-bicd and sent to each host/device for firmware updates.  This differs from the standard OEM commands which are initiated from the host and sent to the BMC.

How do we deal with interactions with the BIC causing other functions to go non-functional?  For example. we have already implemented code in dbus-sensors for IPMB-based sensors and GPIOs.  Doesn't code update cause those to go offline temporarily?  How is this interaction handled?

I think, IPMB-based sensors and GPIOs Implementation would be changed to handle the states machines like Software_update_in_progress. Current dbus-sensors handles only PowerState like Running, on or off only. We can add Software_update_in_progress state with PowerState enum or we can handle it separately. 

These states would be set based on BIC/other device current status. While Software_update_in_progress state, we should not process IPMB-based sensors and GPIOs. We should wait until BIC update is completed.
Exposing the dbus interface for inter-module communications (TBD)
firmware update.  The proposed name of the daemon is "ocp_bicd".
Images will be read and validated.
3) If the image is valid, device details are obtained and used to update the devices (ex. CPLD, voltage regulator, BIOS, etc.)
We should probably make reference to the Software design since we're just going to be implementing the ItemUpdater portion of that.

from the ocp_bicd daemaon

Please be consistent in the naming of the daemon.  In some areas, you have it as ocp_bicd and in others, ocp-bicd.
BIC will handle these OEM commands and send a response to ipmbbridged.
If an error response is received, then the firmware update is considered to have failed.

Is ocp_bicd a flashing tool or is this a feature of ocp-bicd?  Based on the earlier statements, I thought it was a feature and not a tool.  If there is a flashing tool, it needs to be called out the role it plays in the process.

The expected user interactions (user initiates X, does Y, etc.) should be shown as well as what the code does.  Reading through this, I can't tell what parts are automated and which require user intervention.
Here, I mentioned user as Openbmc users who wanted to do OCP firmware update like BIOS/BIC/CPLD update, then they can use this ocp_bicd in BMC. ocp-bicd gets the image and does the firmware update.
ocp_bicd daemon is doing the flashing. This we can call as flashing tool.

Why isn't the ocp-bicd monitoring the information presented by phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt's dbus interfaces and making its own interfaces for doing the update?  Why are we running an application named '...d' (as in daemon) in a non-daemon manner?
ocp-bicd - most of the daemons named with 'd'. For example ipmid, ipmbbridged. So just added 'd' with ocp_bic.
Ack. ocp-bicd can monitor the information produced by phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt's dbus interfaces. Updated the doc accordingly.

this should be more generic as how the BIC performs the firmware update is outside the scope of the ocp_bicd daemon's work.  

I would suggest changing this to "the BIC performs the BIOS firmware update"

I'm confused here.  Is the BMC downloading the firmware image to the BIC?  This implies the BMC is doing the BMC FW update by downloading 224 bytes per packet and the BIC is just a pass through interface.  It would be better to understand what is going on at both the BMC and BIC at this step.

Yes. BMC gets the firmware image to the BIC. BMC is doing all FW udpates like CPLD, BIOS, VR by downloading 224 bytes per packet and BIC just a pass through interface.

Updated the same in the doc.

IPMB timeout

There are other timeouts, but this retry is based off the IPMB timeout only.

This is confusing.  I think this should be "If all 3 retries timeout, the update..."

It appears based on the wording that only 2 retries are done as the retry time reaches 3 stops the update.
What errors are logged and how is the user notified the update has timed out?
Ocp_bicd sends the images to BIC for BIOS update. if IPMB Timeout or error occurs, this daemon returns error. So, need to re-initiate the update.
which contains the offset and data length of the firmware update image so the BIC can verify the image.

I think this is outside the scope of this change.

I think what is expected here is something like...

"Bridge IC will verify the image and return the checksum to the BMC"
What process is repeated here?  Shouldn't the BMC verify the checksum received from the BIC and if correct, report the update a success?
Yes. BMC should verify the checksum received from the BIC and if correct, report the FW update as success. Updated the same in the doc.

I would remove "SPI" as that is up to the BIC implementer to determine the bus type to use.

Also, remove the word ROM from "BIOS ROM" as the ROM is not being updated.  Only the SRAM image is being updated as the ROM is baked into silicon.

Current Implementation in bmcweb supports only single host for all the features. To support multi host implementation bmcweb needs to be updated. Features list include s software update of BIOS, CPLD, VR also.
Who performs this operation?  Is it the user, BMC, BIC?
Unfortunately, fb-ipmi-oem code only handles incoming OEM commands.  fb-ipmi-oem requests use handler functions and send responses back to the requester.
the MAINTAINERS have discouraged use of openbmc-tools for our needs.

VR firmware update is mentioned in several places, but how this would handle that support is missing from this design doc.

Also, BIC FW updates are needed for YV3.5 and other future platforms so should have a section for how these would be accomplished as well.
Need to define what "This" is.  It is vague.
this code will need to be placed in a new repository.
Didn't you imply there were changes to bmcweb needed?
Ack. Bmcweb needs to be updated for Redfish support.
Are we going to write unit tests for this application?
Not immediately. We plan to complete the application with usual testing. Later can we add unit tests for all the functions.

Hi All, 

  Could you please review this patch and provide your comments if any.

Thanks,

Based on what is in the doc, I would remove all references to VR, CPLD and BIC FW updates and just focus on BIOS FW update.  The section on CPLD is empty and the VR and BIC FW updates are not listed at all.  The only section which is completed is BIOS, which is a good first step on this.  

I would also change the document title to indicate this is OCP_BIC_multi-host_OEM-BIOS_firmware-update_implementation (or something similar) so it is clear this is only referencing the BIC in general terms and is specific to how to perform BIOS firmware updates in a multi-host environment.  Once the BIOS updates are implemented, additional Design docs can be submitted to indicate how other types of FW updates can be performed, building on the base use case for this interface.
Done. Updated the doc to have only BIOS FW update implementation.
Would be good to also edit the diff title so it reflects the updated nature of this change.
Updates to the doc look good.  Can you update the title for this diff so it aligns with the updated doc as it isn't a BIC design doc anymore...just focused on BIOS FW updates using a BIC.
just for my reference what is BIC exactly. Maybe add some background here.
anything blocking the BMC from updating the BIOS directly? Or this assume that the BMC doesn't have access to the BIOS?

BMC doesn't have the access of BIOS flash directly. The BIC has the control of firmware updates and flash updates. So, we have to send the IPMI command to BIC for requesting the firmware update of BIOS.
have you take a look at phosphor-ipmi-flash? That can be used to update any firmware in general.

phosphor-ipmi-flash is different, It uses the BLOB protocol to transfer the firmware image. It follows the commands based on BlockTransfer. But this is more specific to IPMI OEM commands. It has OEM based netfn and cmds for requesting firmware update and image transferring. So, we cannot use phosphor-ipmi-flash.

As discussed in the call this week, this doc needs to be either a part of a set indicating the features which need to be implemented to communicate with a BIC or needs to expand its scope so it aligns with the original intent to describe how oBMC should communicate with a BIC to handle various functions and why a separate repo is needed for BIC specific interaction code.
Sorry it took so long to get here.  The existing IPMB BIC code has taken quite a bit of time, and it seemed like that was more important to this initiative.
Ack. Working on creating BIC document which is parent document for this and it indicates the BIC related features.

no problem. As I mentioned below, working creating parent doc for this doc which have all the BIC functionalities and requesting for the new repo. This doc focuses on BIOS firmware update. Also, will submit series of docs to explain about each firmware updates like CPLD, VR etc

How does this relate to the implementation going into dbus-sensors?  Would we move the existing patchsets and IPMB code to this new repo?  As a general rule, managing external controllers from more than one daemon leads to problems.  For example, while doing a firmware update, generally sensors should stop scanning to avoid conflicts and unintended errors.  Having that kind of interlocking between two daemons is error prone.

I'm fine if this logic goes into the new daemon in dbus-sensors you're abstracting, or if you want this in a new repo, but splitting up control is IMO a bad idea.

As of now, we don't have any plans to move IPMB sensors to this new repo. we add all BIC related implementations(Ex : firmware updates, Power control, GPIO state related stuffs) to this new repo. 

I am working creating parent doc for this doc which have all the BIC functionalities and requesting for the new repo. This doc focuses on BIOS firmware update. Also, will submit series of docs to explain about each firmware like CPLD, VR etc.

There have been distributed firmware update dbus API proposals (there's I think 3 in review)  that are intending to break the reliance on "one dbus firmware update service to rule them all" and distribute the interfaces better.  Have you looked at or considered those designs at all?
Validated how?  Read from where?   Lots of details missing here that are important to the design.
This can probably be removed.  The IPMBbridged interface isn't changing in this design, and this section doesn't add any value over the example busctl command.
Any recovery or retry required here?
How does this section differ from "The implementation flow of OEM firmware update"?  It seems like the same flow, just with different words and names.  Can they be combined?
The "user" doesn't have direct access to the bmc generally.  How would a user normally use this?  IPMI?  Redfish?  SSH?

I think there's a misunderstanding about what a daemon does here.  A daemon is started at startup, and allows interaction through the lifecycle of the system.  Generally a user would not be able to launch a daemon directly.

I suspect some kind of user-facing dbus interface is required here.

Lots more details needed here:
1. What schemas are you planning on adding?
2. What new features (http multipart) are you planning on adding?
3. How would a user interact with a given firmware component?


If you don't have the answers today, and would prefer to deal with this incrementally in bmcweb code, that's fine with me, but it's definitely worth discussing.
Good alternative, and good explanation why it's not possible
openbmc-tools is a repo, it's not clear what this would even entail using openbmc-tools to implement the above firmware updates.

Surely this isn't the case.
